name: Tuna Tataki
description: My Tuna Tataki recipe is an easy way to serve fresh sashimi-grade fish at home. In this Japanese technique, we quickly pan-sear the tuna and serve it rare on the inside with a drizzle of ginger ponzu sauce. It‘s a delicious treat for seafood lovers!
recipeIngredient: 1 tsp ginger ((grated, with juice; from a 1-inch, 2.5-cm knob))
3 Tbsp ponzu ((you can make my Homemade Ponzu recipe))
Korean chili thread ((I used mild chili threads))

recipeInstructions.text: Grate the ginger and collect 1 tsp ginger (grated, with juice). Slice 1 green onion/scallion thinly and set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Grate the ginger and collect 1 tsp ginger (grated, with juice). Slice 1 green onion/scallion thinly and set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Combine the sauce ingredients in a small bowl: the green onions, the grated ginger, 3 Tbsp ponzu, 2 tsp toasted sesame oil, 1 tsp soy sauce, and 1 tsp toasted white sesame seeds. Set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Combine the sauce ingredients in a small bowl: the green onions, the grated ginger, 3 Tbsp ponzu, 2 tsp toasted sesame oil, 1 tsp soy sauce, and 1 tsp toasted white sesame seeds. Set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Heat a nonstick frying pan. When the pan is hot, add 2 Tbsp neutral oil. When the oil is hot, add ½ lb sashimi-grade yellowfin/ahi tuna and sear it 30 seconds on each side.
recipeInstructions.name: Heat a nonstick frying pan. When the pan is hot, add 2 Tbsp neutral oil. When the oil is hot, add ½ lb sashimi-grade yellowfin/ahi tuna and sear it 30 seconds on each side.

recipeInstructions.text: When all sides are seared, remove from the heat and let it cool. Slice the tuna into ¼-inch (6-mm) pieces. Pour the sauce on the Tuna Tataki and serve with ½ lemon and Korean chili thread.
recipeInstructions.name: When all sides are seared, remove from the heat and let it cool. Slice the tuna into ¼-inch (6-mm) pieces. Pour the sauce on the Tuna Tataki and serve with ½ lemon and Korean chili thread.

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for a day.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for a day.

review.reviewBody:
I've sort of been waffling between this recipe for Tuna Tataki and another, the other involved coating the tuna with ginger and sesame seeds before cooking. I like this one better, but the one takeaway from the other is to slice the tuna halfway through before cooking, so it's easier to slice once cooked. I found the Korean Chili Threads from Amazon, and I think these delicate threads just enhance the Tataki. As the other recipe suggested, I'll serve this on top of some micro greens, and perhaps sprinkle some delicate bean sprouts on top, along with the Chili Threads.

I'm also going to make fresh spring rolls to complete the meal. I love your recipes!
Definitely a special meal. I would make this for a guest who doesn't like the idea of raw fish but is comfortable with eating it "rare".
I just made the miso glazed eggplant and tuna tataki and both were delicious  and so easy to make! I’m looking forward to making more of your recipes!!

Since I have moved to Tokyo almost 5 years ago this is my website to go to for Japanese cooking . I love it !! Easy recipes, perfectly explained . If it’s ok , I would
Like to share your website on the Tokyo mother’s group because I think it would be very helpful
